answers.author: Michael Baker
answers.text:
To answer the member's question, I know of no municipality that has situated their key management staff this way.  
In my mind, the larger question suggested here is - how does a manager effectively communicate with their direct reports while ensuring that those managers and directors have effective and productive working relationships with the employees within their departments? 
Here are some of the ways we've attempted to address this issue: 
1. Encourage managers to conduct regularly scheduled weekly one-on-one meetings (approx. 30 minutes long) between the manager and each individual direct report.   I've been doing them for nearly four years and even with seven direct reports, it represents an extremely valuable and effective use of my time.  
1. Provide venues for and encourage "hotelling", where employees whose primary office is in one facility can conduct work from another building. 
3. Equip staff with mobile technologies and access to information that make it easier to work from anywhere.   We've done this by shifting to Google Email/Apps and either providing smartphones or tablets or allowing employees to bring their own devices (BYOD). 
In my experience, we've seen greater productivity and alignment within departments and greater cooperation across departments as a result of these actions.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
The primary job of the Director is to run the Department.  I think that becomes much more difficult if they are not in the department but in a separate building.  It can adversely affect communications and the connectivity and credibility with the Department employees.  I see no reason that a City Manager needs a Department immediately adjacent at their beckon call.  This is especially true with email, smart phones and video calling.  I have found the once a week staff meeting and asking them ot come over when needed more then sufficient.

answers.author: John Zakian
answers.text:
For what it is worth, my experience from several of my positions has been there is a very strong, resounding rationale for department directors to be in the same location as support staff because otherwise it can create morale challenges with staff feeling isolated, lack a sense of a strong chain of command and communication, and lack a sense of shared commitment to mission and services.

author: Gregory Stopka
text: I have a member that is interested in how cities structurally place directors in their municipality.  For example, the City Manager is considering moving all of the directors of each department into one building with him; while leaving some of the support staff in other locations.  Has anyone done anything like this?
title: Directors in One Building
